Abandoned

Squashed into [Add mctpreactor for dynamic configuration of MCTP networks](https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/69111)

nit:

```
auto path = msg.unpack<object_path>();
```

This avoids a pointless construction and allows potential RVO from the `read` path (which saves a copy/move).
Acknowledged
Done
If you read this as a `set<string>` you can use `contains` on line 50, since you don't seem to need the results.
Acknowledged
Done
nit: same unpack usage.
Acknowledged
Done
nit: `std::ranges::find(removedInterfaces,`
Acknowledged
Done

There's never really any documentation on what this is intended to do.

It looks like it:
- Registers a remove match.
- Calls 'added'.

It isn't clear why this is "correct".
Acknowledged

I've added some documentation for the method to the header. However, I'm unclear whether your concern is that the method is too miscellaneous and there's a better abstraction that I've missed, or if it was just a lack of documentation to measure the implementation against.

Let me know if your concern is the former, as adding documentation won't fix it.
I wonder why the mctp APIs use a string for an object_path?
The intent is to abstract the implementation from DBus specifics for testing purposes.

I'm not sure what the response was in reference to, but my comment was that this seems like a flaw in the mctpd implementation (and a common one that I see often).  If something is an object_path, it should be returned as an object_path and not a string.  We have the same problem in mapper though where originally all the dbus interfaces were specified as object_path but then the mapperx implementation only used strings.  They end up being roughly equivalent but obvious express intent poorer.

> I'm not sure what the response was in reference to, but my comment was that this seems like a flaw in the mctpd implementation (and a common one that I see often).

Sorry, yes, I see what you mean now. That had occurred to me also but I haven't thought about fixing it yet.
It isn't clear to me why parts of this flow belong in a lambda and parts of it belong in `finaliseEndpoint`.
Acknowledged

I've added a comment. I'm not sure it will be satisfactory, so let me know if you have a preference for an alternative approach. I guess I've been inconsistent, e.g. `std::bind_front(MctpdDevice::onEndpointInterfacesRemoved, ...)`. Do you prefer that approach instead?
Any reason to not use lg2 interfaces?
No, that was an oversight. I iterated a fair bit on all this. lg2 was one of the later additions, and my conversion was clearly incomplete.
Done
Can we use `std::format` for this?  It seems like it would be more readable (and from my experiments, likely smaller code).
From my experiments `std::format` lacked support for formatting vectors in `c++20`.

Agreed on the vectors piece.  stringstream doesn't really either though.  In both cases you'd need a for-loop + string concatenation.  I still think `std::format` tends to be more readable, especially with stuff like line 162.
Done
Any reason to not put this in the header at the definition point?  Doesn't seem like it really does anything and 70% of the lines are duplicated.
Sure, I can put it in the header instead. Just wary of compile times, but at least it's not templated.
Done
These can also be a single unpack call (or 3 if you prefer the readability of that).
Acknowledged
Done
Would std::format be more readable here?
Acknowledged
Done

Since every method is "virtual" this seems like an "interface class" (in the Java sense).  You should also create a virtual destructor.

```
virtual ~MctpDevice() = default;
```

I have to say though, I don't really understand the point of the virtual class when there is only one implementation.  Is there really ever going to be more than one?

Ack to the virtual destructor, that was an oversight.

Anyway, yes, you're right to question its existence. My intent was that it will help with separation of concerns for the purpose of testing. I'll address that by adding some tests.
Done

To clarify, I fixed the virtual destructor situation. I'll punt on the tests for the moment so I can push the fixes for the rest of the comments. Un-marking this as resolved to track adding test cases.
nit: Can you create a using alias for these function types (and the one on line 122)?
Acknowledged
Done
nit: setMTU ?
It's not required for what I'm proposing here anyway, so I'll remove it for now.
Do you want this to be the shared_ptr or a weak_ptr?  Not clear what this is used for because there aren't any users.

I will squash this patch into [Add mctpreactor for dynamic configuration of MCTP networks](https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/69111) to improve visibility a bit there. My thought with separating them was would help keep the patch size manageable, but if it's harder to review due to the missing context then separation isn't helping anything.
Virtual destructor needed.
Acknowledged
Done

There is no MctpdDevice::removed though?

I'm not a big fan of 'remove' and 'removed'.  I don't really know which does what.

Why can't the destructor handle 'removed'?

> There is no MctpdDevice::removed though?

Hah, yeah, let me fix that.

> I'm not a big fan of 'remove' and 'removed'. I don't really know which does what.

I'm also not super happy with that naming. However:

- `remove()`: Some event has occurred that causes us an imperative need to remove the endpoint
- `removed()`: An event has occurred outside of our control that has removed the endpoint, and we're responding to its removal.

> Why can't the destructor handle 'removed'?

Let me try to recall what was going on there and follow up with some better documentation.
Done
This was written by someone using en-gb. 😄
Is this a request for `en-us`?
